citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
A young adult female white-tailed deer, with eartag #41, was extremely thin. Her spine, ribs, hip bones, and shoulder
bones were readily apparent from a distance. She was hanging around the prep kitchen, where veggie scraps were
frequently tossed out for her to eat. The safari area had abundant grass and other vegetation. The licensee was aware of
her condition but thought she wasn't adjusting to being out on safari. The licensee had not contacted the vet nor initiated
any treatment such as deworming. If daily observations of animals are not communicated to the vet in a timely manner
and appropriate methods to diagnose and treat disease are delayed, animals can suffer pain, distress, and death. Correct
by frequently communicating health conditions to the vet and initiating appropriate treatment promptly. Correct by 6/4/25.

Five Oryx died in February 2025 during an extended cold snap, where daily lows were near or below freezing for
approximately 2 weeks and precipitation occurred on 4 days. The Safari area is heavily wooded with deciduous trees and
a horse barn was left open towards the front entrance of the safari. The licensee stated that he burned bonfires during the
cold snap but the oryx always stayed back and while he saw them towards the front of the safari at night, he never saw
them enter the barn. No necropsies were performed but the attending vet assumed they had froze to death. As an African
antelope species, Oryx have both a thinner haircoat and are more lean than deer acclimated to colder climates and are
more likely to suffer negative consequences when subjected to extremely cold temperatures with or without precipitation.
When climatic conditions present a threat to an animal's health, appropriate measures must be taken to alleviate the
impact of those conditions. An animal may never be subjected to any combination of temperature, humidity, and time that
is detrimental to the animal's health or well-being, taking into consideration such factors as the animal's age, species,
breed, health status, and acclimation. Correct from 6/3/25 forward.

Inside the front gate of the main pasture, off to the left side there was numerous piles of debris, gates and other materials.
The animals housed in the pasture do have access to this area. The hoofstock could climb on the debris and get injured
or become entrapped. The debris must be removed from the areas that animals have access to. Premises (buildings and
grounds) must be kept clean and in good repair to protect the animals from injury. To be corrected by: 07-03-2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
COURTNEY JERNIGAN, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
A young adult female white-tailed deer, with eartag #41, was extremely thin. Her spine, ribs, hip bones, and shoulder 
bones were readily apparent from a distance. She was hanging around the prep kitchen, where veggie scraps were 
frequently tossed out for her to eat. The safari area had abundant grass and other vegetation. The licensee was aware of 
her condition but thought she wasn't adjusting to being out on safari. The licensee had not contacted the vet nor initiated 
any treatment such as deworming. If daily observations of animals are not communicated to the vet in a timely manner 
and appropriate methods to diagnose and treat disease are delayed, animals can suffer pain, distress, and death. Correct 
by frequently communicating health conditions to the vet and initiating appropriate treatment promptly. Correct by 6/4/25. 
2.131(e)  Critical
   
Handling of animals. 
Five Oryx died in February 2025 during an extended cold snap, where daily lows were near or below freezing for 
approximately 2 weeks and precipitation occurred on 4 days. The Safari area is heavily wooded with deciduous trees and 
a horse barn was left open towards the front entrance of the safari. The licensee stated that he burned bonfires during the 
cold snap but the oryx always stayed back and while he saw them towards the front of the safari at night, he never saw 
them enter the barn. No necropsies were performed but the attending vet assumed they had froze to death. As an African 
antelope species, Oryx have both a thinner haircoat and are more lean than deer acclimated to colder climates and are 
more likely to suffer negative consequences when subjected to extremely cold temperatures with or without precipitation. 
When climatic conditions present a threat to an animal's health, appropriate measures must be taken to alleviate the 
impact of those conditions. An animal may never be subjected to any combination of temperature, humidity, and time that 
is detrimental to the animal's health or well-being, taking into consideration such factors as the animal's age, species, 
breed, health status, and acclimation. Correct from 6/3/25 forward. 
3.131(c) 
   
Sanitation. 
Inside the front gate of the main pasture, off to the left side there was numerous piles of debris, gates and other materials. 
The animals housed in the pasture do have access to this area. The hoofstock could climb on the debris and get injured 
or become entrapped. The debris must be removed from the areas that animals have access to. Premises (buildings and 
grounds) must be kept clean and in good repair to protect the animals from injury. To be corrected by: 07-03-2025.

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
COURTNEY JERNIGAN, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
